frontend.abstract module

Model ini tidak di daftarkan ke __init__.py karena tidak ada migrasi untuk model abstract

class frontend.abstract.BaseAbstractModel(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Model

This model defines base models that implements common fields like: slug created_at updated_at

All Model that have this field, just inheritance from this abstract model # ref : https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3936182/using-a-uuid-as-a-primary-key-in-django-models-generic-relations-impact

class Meta

Bases: object

app_label = 'frontend'
ordering = ['-updated_at']
created_at

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

get_next_by_updated_at(*, field=<django.db.models.fields.DateTimeField: updated_at>, is_next=True, **kwargs)

frontend.calendar module

frontend.calendar.add_new_events(request, default_cal, credentials_path, event_name, start, end, description)
frontend.calendar.index(request)
frontend.calendar.is_event_exists(gcalendar, start_date, end_date, event_summary=None)

Check, if event summary already exists in calendar Param: calendar: is google calendar (GCAL) event_summay: name of event start_date, end_date: clear enough

IF:

event_summary=None True if event exists in range start_date and end_date

ELSE:

Cek range and event_summary too

frontend.calendar.sync_calendar(request, cal, default_cal, credentials, date=None)

Syncronize cal dan calendar default

frontend.calendar.sync_calendar_all(request, year=None, month=None)
if date=None:

get date now

frontend.models module

Model untuk django_authbox, villa, dll # import random # GenericForeignKey, # from django.contrib.contenttypes.models import ContentType # from embed_video.fields import EmbedVideoField # from django.db.models import signals

class frontend.models.AboutUs(id, uuid, created_at, updated_at, is_initial_data, site, admin, view_count, slug, status)

Bases: BaseAbstractModel, BaseGalleryModel, TranslatableModel

exception DoesNotExist

Bases: ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned

Bases: MultipleObjectsReturned

admin

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

admin_id
content

Descriptor for translated attributes.

This attribute proxies all get/set calls to the translated model.

created_at

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

get_next_by_created_at(*, field=<django.db.models.fields.DateTimeField: created_at>, is_next=True, **kwargs)
get_next_by_updated_at(*, field=<django.db.models.fields.DateTimeField: updated_at>, is_next=True, **kwargs)
get_previous_by_created_at(*, field=<django.db.models.fields.DateTimeField: created_at>, is_next=False, **kwargs)
get_previous_by_updated_at(*, field=<django.db.models.fields.DateTimeField: updated_at>, is_next=False, **kwargs)
get_status_display(*, field=<django.db.models.fields.SmallIntegerField: status>)
id

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

is_initial_data

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

photo

Accessor to the related objects manager on the one-to-many relation created by GenericRelation.

In the example:

class Post(Model):
    comments = GenericRelation(Comment)

post.comments is a ReverseGenericManyToOneDescriptor instance.

save(*args, **kwargs)

Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to control the saving process.

The ‘force_insert’ and ‘force_update’ parameters can be used to insist that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for non-SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.

site

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

site_id
slug

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

status

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

sub_title

Descriptor for translated attributes.

This attribute proxies all get/set calls to the translated model.

title

Descriptor for translated attributes.

This attribute proxies all get/set calls to the translated model.

translations

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

news_set

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

pages_set

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

save(*args, **kwargs)

Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to control the saving process.

The ‘force_insert’ and ‘force_update’ parameters can be used to insist that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for non-SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

file_path_doc

The descriptor for the file attribute on the model instance. Return a FieldFile when accessed so you can write code like:

>>> from myapp.models import MyModel
>>> instance = MyModel.objects.get(pk=1)
>>> instance.file.size

Assign a file object on assignment so you can do:

>>> with open('/path/to/hello.world') as f:
...     instance.file = File(f)

calendar_id

created_at

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

file_path_doc

The descriptor for the file attribute on the model instance. Return a FieldFile when accessed so you can write code like:

>>> from myapp.models import MyModel
>>> instance = MyModel.objects.get(pk=1)
>>> instance.file.size

Assign a file object on assignment so you can do:

>>> with open('/path/to/hello.world') as f:
...     instance.file = File(f)

googlecalendardetail_set

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

save(*args, **kwargs)

Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to control the saving process.

The ‘force_insert’ and ‘force_update’ parameters can be used to insist that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for non-SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.

Accessor to the related objects manager on the forward and reverse sides of a many-to-many relation.

In the example:

class Pizza(Model):
    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

title

This attribute proxies all get/set calls to the translated model.

Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to control the saving process.

The ‘force_insert’ and ‘force_update’ parameters can be used to insist that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for non-SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.

save(*args, **kwargs)

Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to control the saving process.

The ‘force_insert’ and ‘force_update’ parameters can be used to insist that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for non-SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.

site

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

site_id
slug

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

This attribute proxies all get/set calls to the translated model.

translations

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

announcement_set

Accessor to the related objects manager on the forward and reverse sides of a many-to-many relation.

In the example:

class Pizza(Model):
    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

photo

Accessor to the related objects manager on the one-to-many relation created by GenericRelation.

In the example:

class Post(Model):
    comments = GenericRelation(Comment)

post.comments is a ReverseGenericManyToOneDescriptor instance.

save(*args, **kwargs)

Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to control the saving process.

The ‘force_insert’ and ‘force_update’ parameters can be used to insist that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for non-SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.
